section.title: Comparatives and superlatives
section.sectiontitle:
To make comparisons, we use adjective + -er/-r/-ier and
the + adjective + -est/-st/-iest.
section.text2: superlatives: the oldest, the largest, the friendliest
section.text2a: It's the oldest university in the country.
section.sectiontitle2: With most  two-syllabled and longer adjectives, we use more + adjective + -er and the most + adjective + -est.
section.text3a: It's more crowded than it used to be.
section.text4a: The most interesting building is the castle.

section.title: Comparative and superlative adjectives
section.text1: good – better – the best; bad – worse – the worst; far – further/farther – the furthest/farthest
section.sectiontitle2: For large differences, we can use far, much or a lot + comparative adjective.
section.text3: Russia is very big. Belgium is quite small.
section.text4: This watch is £70. That watch is £20.
section.text4a: This watch is much more expensive than that one.

section.title: Comparative and superlative adjectives
section.sectiontitle: For small differences, we can use a little/a little bit/slightly + comparative adjective.
section.text1: Jane and Sarah are 19. Jane's birthday is in May and Sarah's is in June.
section.text1a: Jane is a bit older than Sarah.
section.text2: The black jacket's £40 and the blue jacket's £38.
section.text2a: The black jacket's slightly more expensive than the blue one.
section.sectiontitle2: With superlatives, we often use by far the/one of the/the second/third etc. + superlative adjective.
section.text3a: Baghdad is one of the oldest cities in the world.
section.text4a: London is the second most expensive city to live in.
